item.title: mbranson_1993 on "What is Digital Humanities?"
item.dc:creator: mbranson_1993
item.description:
And this last one is perhaps the most useful for me:

"I would define it as the intersection between computing technologies and research and teaching in the humanities. Influenced by web technologies, it also promotes collaborative approaches to scholarship." — Alexandra Guerson

This definition resonates with me in a couple of ways: first, I concur with the idea of "collaborative approaches to scholarship." Our digital world certainly allows--perhaps, encourages--collaboration. Also, as Terry Heick asserts: ". . .the 21st century’s model is form and interdependence." Web 2.0, I believe, has positioned us for Heick's assertion and the very collaboration in this definition.

I have to "ditto" what I have just said to the idea in the definition of "computing technologies and research." It is far easier to access information with something as mundane as a search function on my browser as it was keeping hundreds of note cards and multiple legal pads from my dissertation research. This "intersection" has radically changed research across all disciplines.

So far--this definition helps me understand the term, but I am puzzled by how this definition informs my teaching and my students' learning.

item.title: mbranson_1993 on "What is Digital Humanities?"
item.dc:creator: mbranson_1993
item.description:
From the same source as above this definition: "As a social construct."— louburnard. . .

This definition certainly avoids the implicit absolutism of the previous one I noted, but it seems incomplete: a social construct of what? who is the "constructor"? from what is this "construction" built?

A problem with metaphors (and construct here is obviously metaphoric) is that they can lead us into directions we did not intend.

item.title: mbranson_1993 on "What is Digital Humanities?"
item.dc:creator: mbranson_1993
item.description:
Here is one definition: "Digital Humanities allow people a new possibility to access knowledge and in turn generates new knowledge." — Michelle Moore

Do I access knowledge or do I access information that, after some reflection and discussion, becomes knowledge? Also, is "knowledge" (which in this quote seems to suggest something "absolute") constant or does it change? For example, we once accepted as "knowledge" that the world as flat (Thomas Friedman notwithstanding), yet today we do not accept this knowledge.

item.title: Josh on "What is Digital Humanities?"
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.description: There are already some great resources for this, particularly http://whatisdigitalhumanities.com/, which consists of over 500 definitions from people who have participated in the annual Day of DH. I've culled together some definitions here as well: http://sites.library.northwestern.edu/dh/. I also suspect that https://twitter.com/DefiningDH will be of some help; although it's not entirely clear to me yet what this project will be, the folks behind it have been collocating many definitional tweets. Good luck on your project!

item.title: DigitalHumanitiesScholar on "What is Digital Humanities?"
item.dc:creator: DigitalHumanitiesScholar
item.description:
Hello Digital Humanists,

I am creating a video from crowdsourced answers to the question "What is Digital Humanities?". I would appreciate any short response you could provide re same and permission to publish your answer in the video. The aim of this project is to provide a brief introduction to DH for novice digital humanists or those who are not familiar with the field.

Looking forward to hearing your suggestions. Please also provide your Twitter username re acknowledging your contribution.

Many thanks,

Róisín O'Brien
